c
1595
Copie of my L. Th
re
rs l
re
to M
r
Bodley./

15 Decem
b
1595 Un
i
Pro
v

page.lettertext:
fol.280r
M
r
Bodley: Her
Ma
tie
hath ben acquainted w
th
your
dispatche of the xxvj
th
of November, wherin thoughe shee
doth finde howe acceptable it is to The
Stat
,
that shee suspendeth
her demaund
; yet can she not remaine satisfied her selfe, w
th
this manner of their proceeding, wherin the worlde must need
perceave, That their respect to her present occasions, is farre
short of here toward
them in the tymes of their greatest necessities.
And therfore, althoughe her Ma
tie
is pleased, that yow doe lett
them knowe That shee (out of love to their estate) is not
disposed nowe to contest w
th
them, but will forbeare to doe
any thing, w
ch
might serve for cullour of any disordre, or
Confusion to aryse amongst them at the tyme when there are
so many devises used to gayne
e Populer w
th
fraudulent offers of
Peace: yet would shee have yo
w
let them knowe, That this
their cold proceeding w
th
her, must need
leave coldnes in her
disposicion, thoughe it must be no smalle matter
that shall worke
ether [seperac
o
n]
or alye nation from them, whose good shee hath preferred before
so many particuler Consideracions of her owne. And therfore
for
e matter of shipping, of w
ch
in their owne l
re
s presented by
M
r
Caron
they make promyse; yo
w
must let them knowe, That
her Ma
tie
look
assuredly for the performance, as a thing wherof
in no wise they must make default, because it will breede
a great confusion in her Ma
ties
owne preparac
o
ns. But for
the sending of their deputies, shee would have them playnely
tolde, That except their meaning be at the tyme of the co
m
inge
(besid
their formallytie of thanksgiving) to make her May
tie
some such overture of present satisfacc
o
n, as may stand w
th
her
honor to receave, wherin her may
tie
wilbe content to admytt the
Considerac
o
n of
e circumstanc
, w
ch
in Reasone they can alleage
for not performance of the former proportion of her demaund
fol.208v
shee shall rather take their publycke comminge as a multiplycac
o
n
of further scorne, then any kynde of honorable satisfacc
o
n.
And therefore shee is pleased yo
w
shall returne to the bodye of
The states this aunswere formerly sett downe; but forasmuche
as none can better deale inwardly, and pryvately w
th
Mons
r
Barnevill
then yo
r
selfe; her may
tie
may be content externally
to digest this manner of dealing for
e tyme, because
e Com
o
n
Enemy shall not make his particuler advantage of any
drynesse betwene the Queene, and them: yet can it not but
worke some Impression of unkyndnesse in her Ma
t
princeley
brest, w
ch
will breake out at one tyme or other, and therfore to
advise him as a good Patryott to them, and a wellwiller to
the Co
m
on cause to worke them to some better fashion, whom yo
w
may assure that if they shall come over presently w
th
power
to offer as good a Project at the least, or a better if it may be,
then that w
ch
he delivered yo
w
at yo
r
last returne, That in suche
case, both shee will particulerly have sence of his good affection
and can be contented that they shall send their deputies, whom shee
will favourably receave as messeng
r
from her friend
and
Neighboure; at w
ch
tyme yo
w
may ether returne in their company
or some fewe dayes before them, as yo
w
see cause. Her may
tie
hath
in this forme given lyke aunswere to their Agent, who I doubt
not will clearely and particulerly Relate the same.
